hm.binkley.util

Class XProperties

  • java.lang.Object
    • java.util.Dictionary<K,V>
      • java.util.Hashtable<Object,Object>
        • java.util.Properties
          • hm.binkley.util.OrderedProperties
            • hm.binkley.util.XProperties
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Serializable, Cloneable, Map<Object,Object>

    public class XProperties
extends OrderedProperties
    XProperties is a java.util.Properties supporting inclusion of other properties files, parameter substition and typed return values. Key order is preserved; keys from included properties are prior to those from the current properties.

    Keys are restricted to Strings.

    Loading processes lines of the form: 

     #include Spring style resource path
    for inclusion. Looks up resource path with a ResourcePatternResolver; loading found resources in turn. Similarly processes resource recursively for further inclusion. Includes multiple resources separated by comma (",") in the same "#include" statement.

    Substitutes in resource paths of the form: 

     #include ${variable}
    or portions thereof. Looks up variable in the current properties, and if not found, in the system properties. If found, replaces the text with the variable value, including "${" and trailing "}".

    Use forward slashes ("/") only for path separators; do not use back slashes ("\").

    Examples:

    files found subdirectories of the classpath
    Text Result
    #include foo/file.properties Includes foo.properties found in the classpath
    #include foo.properties, bar.properties Includes both foo.properties and bar.properties
    #include file:/var/tmp/${user.name }/foo.properties Includes foo.properties found in a directory named after the current user
    #include classpath*:**&#47;foo.properties Includes all foo.properties
    See Also:
    PathMatchingResourcePatternResolver, StrSubstitutor, XPropsConverter, loading properties with inclusions, loading properties with inclusions, getting properties with substitution, Serialized Form
    Pending:
    Implement defaults, Converter assumes cacheable keys; is this correct?

      • getObject

        @Nullable
public <T> T getObject(@Nonnull
                                  String key)
        Gets a typed property value. Responsibility is the caller's to assign the return to a correct type; failure to do so will cause a ClassCastException at run-time.

        Typed keys are of the form: <var>type</var>:<var>key</var>. The key is the same key as System.getProperty. See register for built-in type key prefixes.

        Examples:

        Code Comment
        Integer foo = xprops.getObject("int:foo"); Gets the "foo" property as an possibly null integer
        int foo = xprops.getObject("int:foo"); Gets the "foo" property as a primitive integer, throwing NullPointerException if missing
        Long foo = xprops.getObject("long:foo"); Gets the "foo" property as an possibly null long; this is the same property as the previous examples
        Type Parameters:
        T - the value type
        Parameters:
        key - the type-prefixed key, never missing
        Returns:
        the type property value, possibly missing
        See Also:
        getObjectOrDefault(String, Object), XPropsConverter.register(String, Conversion)
